original_prompt: You are supposed to identify the category of a high-school level math question. There are five possible categories (1) algebra (2) arithmetic (3) measurement (4) numbers, and (5) probability. Use the following guidelines: (1) 'algebra' questions will typically contain letter variables and will ask you to find the value of a variable (2) 'arithmetic' questions will ask the sum, difference, multiplication, division, power, square root or value of expressions involving brackets (3) 'measurement' questions are questions that ask to convert a quantity from some unit to some other unit (4) 'numbers' questions will be about bases, remainders, divisors, GCD, LCM etc. (5) 'probability' questions will ask about the probability of the occurrence of something. A question must belong to only one category.
generated_prompts: You are tasked with determining the category of a high-school level math question. There are five potential categories: (1) algebra, (2) arithmetic, (3) measurement, (4) numbers, and (5) probability. To identify the category, use the following guidelines: (1) 'algebra' questions contain letter variables and ask for the value of a variable, (2) 'arithmetic' questions ask for the sum, difference, multiplication, division, power, square root or value of expressions containing brackets, (3) 'measurement' questions require conversion of a quantity from one unit to another, (4) 'numbers' questions are about bases, remainders, divisors, GCD, LCM, etc., and (5) 'probability' questions ask about the likelihood of something happening. A question must belong to only one category.

Your task is to identify the category of a high-school level math question, which can be one of the five categories: algebra, arithmetic, measurement, numbers, and probability. For 'algebra' questions, there will usually be letter variables and you need to find the value of a variable. For 'arithmetic' questions, you need to calculate the sum, difference, multiplication, division, power, square root or value of expressions involving brackets. 'Measurement' questions require you to convert a quantity from one unit to another. 'Numbers' questions will involve bases, remainders, divisors, GCD, LCM, etc. 'Probability' questions are about the chance of something happening. Each question can only belong to one category.

You will be presented with a high-school level math question, and you need to identify which one of five categories it belongs to. These categories are (1) algebra, (2) arithmetic, (3) measurement, (4) numbers, and (5) probability. For an 'algebra' question, it will typically contain letter variables and ask you to find the value of a variable. An 'arithmetic' question will involve operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, powers, and square root. A 'measurement' question will require you to convert a quantity from one unit to another. For a 'numbers' question, it will be about topics such as bases, remainders, divisors, GCD, LCM, and so on. Lastly, a 'probability' question will ask about the probability of something occurring. Note that a question must only belong to one category.
